node_runs.output:
Because sunlight is made of many colors, and our atmosphere scatters some colors more than others.

- Sunlight (white light) hits the atmosphere, which contains gas molecules.
- Shorter wavelengths (blue and violet) scatter more than longer wavelengths (red).
- The scattered blue light goes in all directions, so when you look up you see blue from everywhere.

Why not violet? The sky isn’t violet mostly because:
- Violet light is scattered even more, but the sky isn’t very violet to our eyes (the atmosphere absorbs a lot of it, and our eyes are less sensitive to violet).

What about sunsets? The light’s path through the atmosphere is longer, so even more blue/green light is scattered out, leaving reds and oranges.

Clouds or pollution can make the sky look gray or whitish because they scatter all colors more equally (Mie scattering).
node_runs.result:
Because sunlight is made of many colors, and our atmosphere scatters some colors more than others.

- Sunlight (white light) hits the atmosphere, which contains gas molecules.
- Shorter wavelengths (blue and violet) scatter more than longer wavelengths (red).
- The scattered blue light goes in all directions, so when you look up you see blue from everywhere.

Why not violet? The sky isn’t violet mostly because:
- Violet light is scattered even more, but the sky isn’t very violet to our eyes (the atmosphere absorbs a lot of it, and our eyes are less sensitive to violet).

What about sunsets? The light’s path through the atmosphere is longer, so even more blue/green light is scattered out, leaving reds and oranges.

Clouds or pollution can make the sky look gray or whitish because they scatter all colors more equally (Mie scattering).
